messages.messageBody:
David, I agree with everything you are saying except the moving
animals thing. This is a frozen moment of perhaps decision or
indecision. Only subjective of course. Lighting, well is it the time
of day or the shade of the tree? John

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "
messages.msgSnippet: Barry, I just remembered that we never finished discussing that great Ko Kinko tsuba with the Kasugane motif. I m particularly fond of the deer. I ve added to
messages.messageBody:
Barry,

I just remembered that we never finished discussing that great Ko Kinko tsuba with the Kasugane motif.

I'm particularly fond of the deer. I've added to the photo on the web-page an illustration from a book on Paleolithic art, describing the same combination of perspectives we see in the deer on the tsuba. This very ancient approach to perspective is not naturalistic in the way we are normally accustomed to seeing, but I think, in the case of this tsuba, it very successfully communicates the kind of imperfect image of deer we receive, looking from a distance in less than optimum light at moving animals.

I think the imperfection of the perspective makes this tsuba more exciting than a it would be if it featured a much more literally modeled image. And the archaic quality, the comparative roughness of the representation of the deer, on the elegant kinko background is more dramatic by the virtue of the extreme contrast between image and background.


http://zincavage.org/KoKinkoKasugane.htm


David Zincavage



----- Original Message -----
From: Barry Thomas
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, April 17, 2006 12:13 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "


I have followed this discussion with great interest and will have to go over it
again I'm sure, but I clearly see what Milt is talking about. To find a stiffer
deer one would have to go to the tundra...

I recall well a tsuba that I found many years ago. It was a small, copper
sanmai awase (if I correctly remember a phrase I haven't uttered for 15 or more
years!) with a touch of silver (tin??) showing stylised (stamped?) waves with a
creature on it that I always thought was an "over-endowed rabbit", but Bob
Haynes told me was a fox!! I wrote to Bob when I saw a similar tsuba in one of
his catalogues. I was amazed when he said this was a very early style of tsuba
ca 1300 - 1400. I had it for years, often looking at it and saying "Do I like
it, or do I not??" Same thing with this deer kinko. I have gazed at Pete
Klein's image on yahoo (I actually have the Lundren Collection book, but it's
out on loan to a 'kinko' mate) for a long time on this sleepless night, and I
ask myself the same question all over again. So David Z, if I could ask you a
question, when you say "I don't collect kinko at all, but this is one of a
small number of cases which, granted a opportunity, would lead me to alter my
policy" I have to ask you "WHY??" Please explain.

If I found this very tsuba I would think it was junk. I don't have to tell you
why. Or do I?? The design spilling into the seppadai I have only seen on tsuba
I didn't care for. The wobbly surface and incredibly bad nanako would kill it
for me. And the stiff deer doesn't do anything for me at all. However, I would
look at the larger than usual kozuka ana and opine "Hmmm, maybe it's early".
Back to my question to myself "Do I like it, or do I not". If I don't like it,
I don't collect it, no matter what the aesthetes say.

Now, this puts me into the rustic class, I know, but there is a point to this
that is not all derisory or derogatory. It is this. It is easy to pick
excellent work amongst Edo period tsuba , even in the iron "wabi-sabi" class,
but the archaic styles, the transition between (if we might say) conceptual
forerunners and the refined later schools is much, much more difficult. Or is
it?? Recall here Milt's hawk tsuba that lead to the present discussion. And I
can show you a tsuba that a well-educated (tsuba knowledge) mate of mine
dismissed as "late, possibly 1920s". It is a masterwork of late Edo/early Meiji
and belongs to a friend of mine. If he gives permission I'll put up some images
of it.

So, to bring this to a close, are there any others inhabiting the same closet as
I??? I know I'm lacking an ability, an aesthetic if you like, to appreciate the
stiff deer kinko in question and it worries me. It seems without thorough study
and training many tsuba in this time frame would indeed be considered junk and
sold off, possibly to an ignominious fate. The other kinko that Pete shows in
two images at the same link does "speak to me". It is from the same time frame
and I find it elegant and refined and would collect it. I think this discussion
parallels the Sue Koto kazuuchimono line of thinking with blades - I don't
collect those either...

Barry Thomas
(Melbourne, Australia)

messages.subject: Re: in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "
messages.msgSnippet: I just wanted to add that the deer are a pair doe and stag. The doe is recumbant signifying calm and the stag is wary and on guard. This may signify the times
messages.messageBody:
I just wanted to add that the deer are a pair doe and stag. The doe
is recumbant signifying calm and the stag is wary and on guard. This
may signify the times the tsuba was made. I wonder if we can ignore
the fact that in Asia the deer was to have mystical properties? John

messages.subject: Re: in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "
messages.msgSnippet: David s tsuba of the maple tree with leaves shows greater sophistication in detail than the original deer/maple tsuba being discussed. The branches really give
messages.messageBody:
David's tsuba of the maple tree with leaves shows greater
sophistication in detail than the original deer/maple tsuba being
discussed. The branches really give a wood feeling with a minimum of
carved accents. The original tsuba I believe is a simple
representation of a still/quiet moment, unmoving, of deer in a
glade. A brief instant of peace/harmony. Quite opposed to, as in a
discussion I have had recently, where certain sukashi motif depict
motion. The stiffness that some observe is, I think, this frozen
tableau and intentional. John

Kyo Shoami are the later generations of Ko Shoami in Kyoto after the
Tokugawa Shogunate took power. Interesting comparison. I've found
you can also see some of the same feeling in the Bizen Shoami.

very

and

if

but

not".
> If I

there is

is

might
> say)

more

present

knowledge)

of
> late
> > Edo/early Meiji

I'll
> put
> > up some images

> > > So, to bring this to a close, are there any others
inhabiting
> the
> > same closet as

> > thorough study

be

kinko
> that
> > Pete shows in
> > > two images at the same link does "speak to me". It is
from
> the
> > same time frame
> > > and I find it elegant and refined and would collect it.
I

could ask you a
> question, when you say "I don't collect kinko at all, but this
is one of a
> small number of cases which, granted a opportunity, would lead me
to alter my
> policy" I have to ask you "WHY??" Please explain.
>
> If I found this very tsuba I would think it was junk. I don't
have to tell you
> why. Or do I?? The design spilling into the seppadai I have
only seen on tsuba
> I didn't care for. The wobbly surface and incredibly bad nanako
would kill it
> for me. And the stiff deer doesn't do anything for me at all.
However, I would
> look at the larger than usual kozuka ana and opine "Hmmm, maybe
it's early".
> Back to my question to myself "Do I like it, or do I not". If I
don't like it,
> I don't collect it, no matter what the aesthetes say.
>
> Now, this puts me into the rustic class, I know, but there is a
point to this
> that is not all derisory or derogatory. It is this. It is easy
to pick
> excellent work amongst Edo period tsuba , even in the iron "wabi-
sabi" class,
> but the archaic styles, the transition between (if we might say)
conceptual
> forerunners and the refined later schools is much, much more
difficult. Or is
> it?? Recall here Milt's hawk tsuba that lead to the present
discussion. And I
> can show you a tsuba that a well-educated (tsuba knowledge) mate
of mine
> dismissed as "late, possibly 1920s". It is a masterwork of late
Edo/early Meiji
> and belongs to a friend of mine. If he gives permission I'll put
up some images
> of it.
>
> So, to bring this to a close, are there any others inhabiting the
same closet as
> I??? I know I'm lacking an ability, an aesthetic if you like, to
appreciate the
> stiff deer kinko in question and it worries me. It seems without
thorough study
> and training many tsuba in this time frame would indeed be
considered junk and
> sold off, possibly to an ignominious fate. The other kinko that
Pete shows in
> two images at the same link does "speak to me". It is from the
same time frame
> and I find it elegant and refined and would collect it. I think
this discussion
> parallels the Sue Koto kazuuchimono line of thinking with blades -
I don't
> collect those either...
>
> Barry Thomas
> (Melbourne, Australia)
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "klepet33319" <Ppeterdds@...>
> To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "
messages.msgSnippet: Before we start discussing it, here is a good picture from the 1977 Christie s Lndgren Sal catalogue: http://zincavage.org/KoKinkoKasugane.htm ... From: Barry
messages.messageBody:
Before we start discussing it, here is a good picture from the 1977 Christie's Lndgren Sal catalogue:

http://zincavage.org/KoKinkoKasugane.htm


----- Original Message -----
From: Barry Thomas
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, April 17, 2006 12:13 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "


I have followed this discussion with great interest and will have to go over it
again I'm sure, but I clearly see what Milt is talking about. To find a stiffer
deer one would have to go to the tundra...

I recall well a tsuba that I found many years ago. It was a small, copper
sanmai awase (if I correctly remember a phrase I haven't uttered for 15 or more
years!) with a touch of silver (tin??) showing stylised (stamped?) waves with a
creature on it that I always thought was an "over-endowed rabbit", but Bob
Haynes told me was a fox!! I wrote to Bob when I saw a similar tsuba in one of
his catalogues. I was amazed when he said this was a very early style of tsuba
ca 1300 - 1400. I had it for years, often looking at it and saying "Do I like
it, or do I not??" Same thing with this deer kinko. I have gazed at Pete
Klein's image on yahoo (I actually have the Lundren Collection book, but it's
out on loan to a 'kinko' mate) for a long time on this sleepless night, and I
ask myself the same question all over again. So David Z, if I could ask you a
question, when you say "I don't collect kinko at all, but this is one of a
small number of cases which, granted a opportunity, would lead me to alter my
policy" I have to ask you "WHY??" Please explain.

If I found this very tsuba I would think it was junk. I don't have to tell you
why. Or do I?? The design spilling into the seppadai I have only seen on tsuba
I didn't care for. The wobbly surface and incredibly bad nanako would kill it
for me. And the stiff deer doesn't do anything for me at all. However, I would
look at the larger than usual kozuka ana and opine "Hmmm, maybe it's early".
Back to my question to myself "Do I like it, or do I not". If I don't like it,
I don't collect it, no matter what the aesthetes say.

Now, this puts me into the rustic class, I know, but there is a point to this
that is not all derisory or derogatory. It is this. It is easy to pick
excellent work amongst Edo period tsuba , even in the iron "wabi-sabi" class,
but the archaic styles, the transition between (if we might say) conceptual
forerunners and the refined later schools is much, much more difficult. Or is
it?? Recall here Milt's hawk tsuba that lead to the present discussion. And I
can show you a tsuba that a well-educated (tsuba knowledge) mate of mine
dismissed as "late, possibly 1920s". It is a masterwork of late Edo/early Meiji
and belongs to a friend of mine. If he gives permission I'll put up some images
of it.

So, to bring this to a close, are there any others inhabiting the same closet as
I??? I know I'm lacking an ability, an aesthetic if you like, to appreciate the
stiff deer kinko in question and it worries me. It seems without thorough study
and training many tsuba in this time frame would indeed be considered junk and
sold off, possibly to an ignominious fate. The other kinko that Pete shows in
two images at the same link does "speak to me". It is from the same time frame
and I find it elegant and refined and would collect it. I think this discussion
parallels the Sue Koto kazuuchimono line of thinking with blades - I don't
collect those either...

Barry Thomas
(Melbourne, Australia)

----- Original Message -----
From: "klepet33319" <Ppeterdds@...>

My My Grandma, what big hitsuana you have!!!

Where did that fake tsuba in the black and white image come from!!!! Ah, this
is indeed a different kettle of fish. I think even Milt might say that this
deer is kicking with a bit of life!! I iamgine that in the hand it would look
even better? I look forward to reading further discussion on this tsuba and
Ko-Kinko in general. Here I must mention Robert Burawoy's little picture book
of early tsuba. I don't have it immediately to hand but Msr Burawoy discusses
early tsuba types with the passion that appears to come from serious and
hard-won knowledge. I'll dig it out and read it again in conjunction with the
present discussion. Could I suggest that those of you who have followed this
discussion with interest should seek out Msr Burawoy's little book if you don't
already have it.

Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "
messages.msgSnippet: I have followed this discussion with great interest and will have to go over it again I m sure, but I clearly see what Milt is talking about.  To find a
messages.messageBody:
I have followed this discussion with great interest and will have to go over it
again I'm sure, but I clearly see what Milt is talking about. To find a stiffer
deer one would have to go to the tundra...

I recall well a tsuba that I found many years ago. It was a small, copper
sanmai awase (if I correctly remember a phrase I haven't uttered for 15 or more
years!) with a touch of silver (tin??) showing stylised (stamped?) waves with a
creature on it that I always thought was an "over-endowed rabbit", but Bob
Haynes told me was a fox!! I wrote to Bob when I saw a similar tsuba in one of
his catalogues. I was amazed when he said this was a very early style of tsuba
ca 1300 - 1400. I had it for years, often looking at it and saying "Do I like
it, or do I not??" Same thing with this deer kinko. I have gazed at Pete
Klein's image on yahoo (I actually have the Lundren Collection book, but it's
out on loan to a 'kinko' mate) for a long time on this sleepless night, and I
ask myself the same question all over again. So David Z, if I could ask you a
question, when you say "I don't collect kinko at all, but this is one of a
small number of cases which, granted a opportunity, would lead me to alter my
policy" I have to ask you "WHY??" Please explain.

If I found this very tsuba I would think it was junk. I don't have to tell you
why. Or do I?? The design spilling into the seppadai I have only seen on tsuba
I didn't care for. The wobbly surface and incredibly bad nanako would kill it
for me. And the stiff deer doesn't do anything for me at all. However, I would
look at the larger than usual kozuka ana and opine "Hmmm, maybe it's early".
Back to my question to myself "Do I like it, or do I not". If I don't like it,
I don't collect it, no matter what the aesthetes say.

Now, this puts me into the rustic class, I know, but there is a point to this
that is not all derisory or derogatory. It is this. It is easy to pick
excellent work amongst Edo period tsuba , even in the iron "wabi-sabi" class,
but the archaic styles, the transition between (if we might say) conceptual
forerunners and the refined later schools is much, much more difficult. Or is
it?? Recall here Milt's hawk tsuba that lead to the present discussion. And I
can show you a tsuba that a well-educated (tsuba knowledge) mate of mine
dismissed as "late, possibly 1920s". It is a masterwork of late Edo/early Meiji
and belongs to a friend of mine. If he gives permission I'll put up some images
of it.

So, to bring this to a close, are there any others inhabiting the same closet as
I??? I know I'm lacking an ability, an aesthetic if you like, to appreciate the
stiff deer kinko in question and it worries me. It seems without thorough study
and training many tsuba in this time frame would indeed be considered junk and
sold off, possibly to an ignominious fate. The other kinko that Pete shows in
two images at the same link does "speak to me". It is from the same time frame
and I find it elegant and refined and would collect it. I think this discussion
parallels the Sue Koto kazuuchimono line of thinking with blades - I don't
collect those either...

Barry Thomas
(Melbourne, Australia)

messages.msgSnippet: Link to scan deer tsuba from Lundgren collection: http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/view/7936?b=3 Aizu Shoami from Torigoye, Tsuba, An
messages.messageBody:
Link to scan 'deer' tsuba from Lundgren collection:

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/view/7936?b=3


Aizu Shoami from Torigoye, 'Tsuba, An Aesthetic Study', abridged:

"By the Genroku era, and after, we have ample evidence of this school
in the mass production of inferior quality tsuba. This work is
little better than shiiremono. The style of this period was a
combination of Shoami and later Umetada school styles. ... The poor
quality of Aizu Shoami tsuba is partially due to the fact that for
two hundred and twenty six years the Kato family governed this
province without giving their patronage to the Shoami artists who
lived there. They made no effort to raise the level of the work
produced, or take an interest in its production. The workers of the
province were forced, as independent artists, to fend for themselves,
seeking work anywhere it might be available. ... At the end of the
Edo age there were two wholesale dealers of 'saikumono' (metal
handiwork) living at Wakamatsu in Aizu. They employed many workers
to fill the orders for the mass productions of the Aizu Shoami
school. ... In Meiji/Taisho they produced all types of copies and
imitations for the Tokyo and foreign market. In addition to the Aizu
style they made Heianjo brass inlay and Heianjo openwork, as well as
Nobuiye, Kaneiye, shingen and famous late kinko artist forgeries and
imitations. In fact, they made any and all styles that had a ready
market with the foreigners of Europe and America. This was the final
fate of the Aizu Shoami school".

Personally I wouldn't draw a comparison with Bungo as they were a
very legitimate area of sword production and these became outright
forgeries and reproductions of poor quality in later Edo.

messages.msgSnippet: John, Milt, Sorry, I don t agree with John, generally Aizu tsuba are low quality. The school was not supported by the local daimyo and they turned out mostly
messages.messageBody:
John, Milt,
Sorry, I don't agree with John, generally Aizu tsuba are low quality. The school was not supported by the local daimyo and they turned out mostly poor pieces, having said that there were a few makers who could produce better tsuba but nothing outstanding. The quality is way below that of even the average Waki-goto artists whose best work could rival that of the Goto main line.
Alan

messages.msgSnippet: Milt - Do you have an image of the deer tsuba you keep referring too? Can you direct me to a book I am likely to have where it may be found? You raised a
messages.messageBody:
Milt -
Do you have an image of the deer tsuba you keep referring too? Can
you direct me to a book I am likely to have where it may be found?
You raised a question earlier, is the taste in schools like Jingo
"learned" because the books and teachers all say it is good? I think
that quality has to be "taught", you have to see and compare many
fine examples to discern it. The teachers taste though may not become
the students. Alan makes a good point, in that we have to know the
tastes of the times to understand why certain themes and materials
were used and what was seen as masterwork in one era may not compare
well to those of another time. However we don't have to blindly
follow the fashions of the past.
If you like it, you like it. Buy and collect what you like. What we
see as clunky and rustic in a bad way, appealed to someone at some
point or your tsuba would not exist. It seems you like it and it
found you, thats a good thing.
-t

messages.subject: Re: in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "
messages.msgSnippet: ... tsuba of around 1850, the taste of the times were totally different. Even the Goto family whose work remains relatively static in design over the centuries
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Alan Bale" <abale@...> wrote:
>
> Milt,
> You cannot compare a ko-kinko tsuba of say, 1550, with an Ishiguro
tsuba of around 1850, the taste of the times were totally different.
Even the Goto family whose work remains relatively static in design
over the centuries had to change and designs of the earlier period
would not be saleable in the late Edo period (i.e. a single flute on a
kozuka),
> Alan
>

with all due respect to the Ko-kinko that " laid the gound work " for
future kinko like Ishiguro......... that deer look " stiff " , sort of
well spent and static taking a rest.
Of course as I mentioned.... stiffness is a state of mind.
Just my opinion and I know no one shares it.........so that's that.

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, You cannot compare a ko-kinko tsuba of say, 1550, with an Ishiguro tsuba of around 1850, the taste of the times were totally different. Even the Goto
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
You cannot compare a ko-kinko tsuba of say, 1550, with an Ishiguro tsuba of around 1850, the taste of the times were totally different. Even the Goto family whose work remains relatively static in design over the centuries had to change and designs of the earlier period would not be saleable in the late Edo period (i.e. a single flute on a kozuka),
Alan

messages.messageBody:
Here's a better scan:

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/view/7936?b=3

Now, this is a very old piece (pre-Edo, as in over 400 yrs) and it
does show some age. This also may have been produced by repouse'
which is very delicate and can have the nanako easily blunted. It
might have had a fukurin at one time but I'm not sure on the
construction method here. As for the deer, it looks nice to me but
beauty is always in the eye of the beholder. Simply put, I'd love to
be able to obtain this piece as it is a wonderful example of early
kinko workmanship, IMHO.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Milt; You realize I would be the last person who would ever disagree with you, BUT as I have a soft spot for good Ko-Kinko tsuba I must tell you that you
messages.messageBody:
Hi Milt;

You realize I would be the last person who would ever disagree with you, BUT as I have a soft spot for good Ko-Kinko tsuba I must tell you that you are blowing smoke, or perhaps having one of those wacky ones, when you make such a comment.

Good Ko-Kinko has excellent nanako, very fine and even, painstakingly produced. If it is uneven, and looks like Nagoya mono then chances are that is what it is.

Good Ko-Kinko shakudo has a beautiful rich dark black purplish color not often found in later kinko works, good weight, and normally a floral or vines style of decoration, simple but elegant and very fine nanako, at least the ones I have.

Just my .02 cents worth of course.

John

ok, Tom,
let's " spin " it from a different angle.......... how about the Ko-
kinko works in soft metal....... the nanako are uneven ( compare to
Goto works ), the degree of realism ( I am thinking along the line of
that deer tsuba in the swedish collection ) is " child-like " and stiff
( doesn't even come close to Ishiguro's work ).............. in short
it's like Nagoya works except they look " aged ".

They are treasured because of the age( or the wabi factor ) ?

Seeking enlightenment ( aka punishment )


Milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "
messages.msgSnippet: Milt - Along with the comments Richard made (I think it was Richard) about the quality of the iron and the overall presentation, what I think makes Jingo
messages.messageBody:
Milt -
Along with the comments Richard made (I think it was Richard) about
the quality of the iron and the overall presentation, what I think
makes Jingo special is the character of the work. It is rustic, it is
rough, yes but all the materials are worked and presented just so.
Nothing more needs to be added, little or nothing could be removed
without destroying the presentation.
Was the first Jingo master a rustic who simply did things his way
naturally with no thought as to the outcome? or was he as Hagihara
has suggested a genius, who was repelled by the trends in kinko work
around him, and inspired by the tea culture of his time to create
works shockingly different from any other artist of his time?
I can't answer the question, but I agree that if you compare the
best of Jingo to other kinko works, it is shockingly different, it is
solid, quiet but powerful and very befitting a samurai. A pleasant
shock indeed, and I think genius as well...
-t

messages.msgSnippet: I remember a young collector Richard being educated by this bloke Milt who spent days talking to him about Wabi-Sabi , it took him a while but Richard finally
messages.messageBody:
I remember a young collector Richard being educated by this bloke Milt
who spent days talking to him about Wabi-Sabi , it took him a while but
Richard finally sort of got it. The lesson was the aesthetic, the
underlying beauty, not what one thinks one sees on the surface. Sound
familiar ?.

Rich

darn, the young ones learn fast.................
p.s. but remember all vegetable diet is not good, once in a while you
need red meat.

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "
messages.msgSnippet: I do not think it s always about how life like the portrayal of the bird is Milt, but about how well the work is executed. In the case of the Jingo tsuba, the
messages.messageBody:
I do not think it's always about how life like the portrayal of the bird
is Milt, but about how well the work is executed. In the case of the
Jingo tsuba, the light wash of gold over the iron I think is the
underlying beauty. The bird probably has little to do with it in
essence. I mean by that, it could be anything other than a bird. It is
the iron first, then the shape and the mimi, then the layout of the
seppa dai and hitsu ana and the design. Then step back and look at the
thing as a whole. It is why kinko mono is held in low esteem. Take away
average or poor work on the top, and there is nothing underneath.

I remember a young collector Richard being educated by this bloke Milt
who spent days talking to him about Wabi-Sabi , it took him a while but
Richard finally sort of got it. The lesson was the aesthetic, the
underlying beauty, not what one thinks one sees on the surface. Sound
familiar ?.

Rich

Alan
